citation.article-title: Deinococcus aerius sp. nov., isolated from the high atmosphere
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Deinococcus aerius sp. nov.
Deinococcus aerius (a.e′ri.us. L. masc. adj. aerius belonging to the air, referring to the isolation site of the type strain).
Colonies are circular, convex, orange-pigmented (non-fluorescent) and shiny with smooth edges.
Cells are spherical, 1.0–1.5 μm in diameter, aerobic, non-spore-forming and non-motile.
Optimum temperature range for growth in mTGE broth is 25–30 °C.
Cells typically grow singly, and in pairs, tetrads and clusters and are resistant to desiccation, and gamma and UV radiation.
Major fatty acids are iso-C17 : 0, iso-C17 : 1ω9c and iso-C15 : 0.
Major peptidoglycan amino acids are d-glutamic acid, glycine, d-alanine, l-alanine and ornithine.
Positive for alkaline phosphatase and β-galactosidase activities and hydrolysis of aesculin, but negative for reduction of nitrate to nitrite.
l-Arabinose, glucosamine, ornithine, glutamate, maltose, sucrose, proline, raffinose, cysteine, lysine and methionine are utilized as carbon sources.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 70.5 mol%.
The type strain, TR0125T (=JCM 11750T=DSM 21212T), was isolated from an air sample collected from the high atmosphere, Japan.
